name: damper
content:
damper noun
(CONTROL)
Add to word list
Add to word list
[ C ] a device that reduces vibration (= fast shaking), for example in an engine: The system includes a motor with appropriate gear transmission and a damper. The new model has new springs and dampers and a sports exhaust. Synonym
dampener
[ C ] a device that stops a piano string from making a sound, that can be stopped from working by pressing a key or pedal: A damper, made of soft felt, presses against each string and prevents it from vibrating until it is wanted. The melody resounds as if the damper pedal were being pressed on a piano.
[ C ] a metal plate in a chimney that can be moved to control the flow of air and make the fire burn faster or more slowly: Vent-free fireplaces have no need for a damper. The worker in the boiler room said he was just about to close the damper when the explosion took place. put a damper on something informal (also put a dampener on something)
to make something less active or less enjoyable: Both the kids were sick while we were in Boston, so that put a damper on things.

Parts of buildings: the fireplace & parts of the fireplace
damper noun
(BREAD)
[ C or U ] mainly Australian English a simple type of bread made with flour and water and without yeast, traditionally cooked on a fire: I wanted to try making damper, a bread that you cook in coals on the ground.
More examplesFewer examplesTea was a picnic of damper (yeast-free bread) straight from the fire and traditional billy tea, brewed over the coals. Eva enjoyed "dampers", a kind of bread without yeast made by the swagmen on their wanderings.
